video.title: My Google Job Interview
video.description:
Jesse Weigel interviewed for a front end engineer position at Google. This is his experience from first contact to on-site interviews!

You can see Jesse live coding on our channel or check out his personal channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCUGkNhK8IEUj8A0vbyJ1Bzw

Jesse talks about his job search in this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cvz3NUQ5-ac

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: Chris Mitchell
topLevelComment.text: It is because you are a white male. You didn't make it passed the first face to face meeting. You might want to look into that. They are being sued by an ex-employee right now.

topLevelComment.author: ethernet
topLevelComment.text: Every YouTube video I see about interviews with Google are for coding jobs. Aren’t there any sales, engineering (other), operations, pm, etc... jobs?

topLevelComment.author: John D
topLevelComment.text: You're a great guy for sure. I'd say this is Google's loss.

topLevelComment.author: Lee Charlie
topLevelComment.text: Is it a must to have project experience? If trying to go from other field to Software engineer(therefore there is no project experience before), is being good at coding challenge (data structure and algorithm from leetcode; have been doing leetcode for half year now) enough to get a job?

topLevelComment.author: Amin Kuhail
topLevelComment.text: I don't appreciate you commenting on interviewers not being English native speakers. The majority of software engineers aren't.  They should have good English without a thick accent, but being a native speaker shouldn't be a requirement, and shouldn't be something that gets talked about at all. It's offensive to be honest for someone like me who has worked so hard on my English for a long time, then someone like you who is lucky to be be a native speaker or has the local culture comments on something like that.

topLevelComment.author: Jeff H Sipe
topLevelComment.text: Jesse Weigel thank you for sharing your experience.  To anyone that has interviewed at Google and received positive feedback, keep trying.  From my experience, we hired more people the second and third time they interviewed because they gained more experience and had a better feel for how Google interviews worked.  In addition, by the end of my time at Google, I mostly sourced only using the internal Google database because so many good people had already interviewed, they just needed another shot.  I hope this advice helps!

replies.author: Nirmal Silwal
replies.text: @Jeff H Sipe thank you for sharing this insightful information.

replies.author: Jaganeeshwar S

topLevelComment.author: Mahmud Ahsan
topLevelComment.text: Great video. Thank you for sharing your interview experience. Many people advise that, take interview as a game and take it just to gain some experience. Otherwise sometimes it may give hard feelings or self disappointments.

topLevelComment.text: Hi, Can you pleas let me know how did you prepare for front end role? What types of coding questions and from where did you prepared?

replies.author: max
replies.text:
Closure, dom manipulation
Promise
Maps/List
Callbacks,
Event delegation - bind
Binary, graphs, search

setTimeout
Protos

topLevelComment.author: OutNProud500
topLevelComment.text: The good part is, you can always reapply in the future. You should try applying to some of the locations on the east coast such as New York, Miami, or even Chicago. Moving across the country would definitely be a hassle with 4 kids!

topLevelComment.author: heq65

topLevelComment.author: Guillermo Arellano
topLevelComment.text: I had similar experience with my Google interview where I studied for the algorithms and data structures, when I hadn't done that since college, 15 years ago! Needless to say, I bombed my first technical phone interview. Didn't even finish it because I was totally caught off guard by the focus on front end. Glad you were able to fly out to Mountain View and make it to the next round. Thanks for sharing.

replies.author: Jesse Weigel
replies.text: Hopefully this video will help other front end candidates know what to expect.

topLevelComment.author: Rushikesh ganesh
topLevelComment.text: I am fresher how I m apply for Google

replies.author: Jesse Weigel
replies.text: Go for it!

topLevelComment.author: Yiou Chen
topLevelComment.text: When I got an on-site from Google as a new grad, the questions I got are all very algorithm and data structure heavy despite  the fact that my resume was mostly front end related.

replies.author: Jesse Weigel
replies.text: @Yiou Chen That makes sense. I think they only ask front end questions if you apply for a specifically front end position.

replies.author: Yiou Chen
replies.text: @Jesse Weigel Yes, I was Computer Science major and I applied the general Software Engineer (new grad) position

replies.author: Jesse Weigel
replies.text: Interesting, did you graduate with a Computer Science degree? I ask because my degree was in business, so I never really had any formal CS training. Maybe that had something to do with the questions. Also, did you apply for a front end position?

replies.author: Guillermo Arellano
replies.text: Yeah, because you were a recent grad. That stuff is ingrained in you in a lot of college computer science courses, but rarely used outside of a university setting. At least that was the case with me. Like me, Jesse hasn't been in college in years and thus the interviewers deferred asking those type of questions.

replies.author: Guillermo Arellano

replies.author: Jesse Weigel

topLevelComment.author: tony tony
topLevelComment.text: if you did't get the job , WHY NOT JUST TELL US THE QUESTIONS?

replies.author: Frosty FF
replies.text: @Guillermo ArellanoKeeping information for yourself is not the best idea. Atleast, tell us the difficulty levels, ofcourse chances of getting same questions are slim...so, whatever.

replies.author: Jesse Weigel
replies.text: @Winter Eh Yep, I did sign an NDA. I really do think that knowing the questions that I was asked wouldn't be that helpful because it is very unlikely that someone would be asked the same questions.

replies.author: Guillermo Arellano
replies.text: I think most people don't like to disclose those questions because they want you to struggle as much as they did getting to those positions at top companies. At least that's what I've seen from most people out in the business world who keep information to themselves.  If he charged you for the questions and answers, would you pay for that information? If so, how much would you pay? Thanks.

replies.author: Winter Eh
replies.text: They probably make you sign a non disclosure just to interview

topLevelComment.text: Thx for this video. A big thank you for your shares

replies.author: Jesse Weigel

topLevelComment.author: Ashish Pancholi
topLevelComment.text:
It's great to hear from you about Google interview. 
Can you please share the coding interview books and other stuffs to prepare from.

Thanks in advance.

replies.author: Jesse Weigel
replies.text: I am planning on making a video about all of the resources that I used soon. I will post it on my channel sometime in the next week most likely.

replies.author: Ashish Pancholi
replies.text: @Guillermo Arellano thanks for the advice.

replies.author: Guillermo Arellano
replies.text: @Ashish Pancholi Python is a good server language. It is a programming language used a lot in coding bootcamps and to code things on hardware, and to perform data science analysis. Like JavaScript, it is quite ubiquitous and powerful. Learn that if you are aiming to become a systems administrator, data scientist, machine learning, robotics maker, or back-end developer. There's a ton of resources out there that are free. But I prefer paid ones. One of them is Pluralsight.net. The other, more expensive, is a guy named Reuven Lerner. Good luck!

replies.author: Ashish Pancholi
replies.text: @Guillermo Arellano thanks for the revert, its quite helpful. Had some queries regarding programming languages such as php, IOT, raspberrypi and python. For future perspective which would be better and how can I learn for the same.

replies.author: Guillermo Arellano
replies.text: Typically when you interview with Google, the recruiter gives you a ton of useful resources for you to prepare. They rock with that aspect. One of those resources is a book called "Cracking The Coding Interview." It's a great book, just for you to understand the way the gatekeepers, other programmers, think and strategize to select individuals into their organizations and their teams.
